dt: {bc}to renounce allegiance or subjection (as to a government) {bc}{sx|rebel||}
{bc}to cause to turn away or shrink with disgust or abhorrence

et: borrowed from Middle French {it}revolter,{/it} as reflexive {it}se revolter{/it} "to turn about, change sides, turn away (from a belief, adherence), rebel," borrowed from Italian {it}revoltare, revottare{/it} (later {it}rivoltare{/it}) "to turn over, turn inside out, cause to rebel, disgust," from {it}re-{/it} {et_link|re-|re-} + {it}voltare{/it} "to turn," going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*volvitāre,{/it} iterative of Latin {it}volvere{/it} "to set in a circular course, cause to roll, bring round" {ma}{mat|wallow:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to renounce allegiance or subjection (as to a government) : rebel
